All the countries and parties involved in the Syrian crisis seem to agree that Moscow is more reliable than Washington in this crisis.
NATO ally Turkey has been working with the Russians for years, despite the fact they back opposing factions in the Syrian civil war. Even arch-enemies Israel and Iran seem to agree that the road to making sure their interests are met runs through Moscow. And when the Kurdish-dominated Syrian Democratic Forces -- which were backed by the US and lost nearly 11,000 fighters in the war against ISIS -- found out they'd been dumped by Trump and left to be invaded by Erdogan's proxy force, they too went straight to the Russians because guess what: Moscow has been working with and talking to the SDF for years as well.
So it was never going to be the Trump White House that could try and broker a solution to the messy situation in northeastern Syria. If there will be deal it will be reached next Tuesday in Sochi by Putin and Erdogan -- on their terms.

A new assessment by IHS Jane’s Conflict Monitor from Wednesday shows the Assad regime may be poised for its biggest territorial gains in more than nine months, and perhaps even years. Assad’s forces have already reentered a number of cities and areas, said Columb Strack, the principal Middle East analyst at IHS Markit, an analysis firm that has tracked the war in Syria. But he cautioned it remained unclear what sort of control regime forces will exert there, both in the short and long run. Syrian forces may initially act as a deterrence to Turkey but not seize full control of the areas, Strack said. That could change in coming weeks, however. While the Syrian government may not yet fully control those areas, its forces now have a more expansive geographical footprint than at any time during the past half decade — a direct result of Trump’s Syria pullout.

After a few hours reading news, checking how the last eight years went on and what are the current events, my conclusion is that there is no way for me to get a probability estimation from the inside view. Thus, I jump directly to the outside view. Assad has survived in power 8 years of civil war. If I make the "ordinary world" hypothesis (this was a 50-50 outcome), then this yields a 1.3% probability of him not holding power in the next 2.5 months. I round it to 1%. Notice that if I have made a "he's been incredibly lucky" (20-80 outcome) hypothesis, this will only raise the probability up to 2.1%, not a really big difference.
At this point, he'd have to die or step down, and I think both of these possibilities are very unlikely.

Graphic News September 6, 2019 -- The Syrian army, backed by Russian airpower, is steadily gaining ground in northwestern Idlib province, the last bastion of opposition forces battling the regime of President Bashar al-Assad. All summer long Syrian and Russian jets have bombed Idlib, destroying homes, hospitals, schools and bakeries, according to The Economist newspaper. The United Nations sought to protect medical facilities by sharing their co-ordinates with Russia, but after dozens of air strikes on hospitals and clinics, doctors came to believe that the no-strike list was in fact being used as a target set. They have stopped sharing their locations. On the ground the Syrian army has retaken Khan Shaykhun, the site of a regime chemical-weapons attack in 2017. The biggest town in the south of Idlib province, it occupies a strategic position along the M5 motorway that connects Damascus to Aleppo.

There is strong precedence for this position.  In the 1930's Russia was massacring, enslaving, and torturing millions of its own citizens who did not tout the soviet/socialist party line. Just as reported in this article, brothers turned in brothers, all to save themselves - if only of a short while (The Gulag Archipelago).  This occurred in Maoist China where 10 of millions died, and in Cuba, and the list goes on.  This has never been the catalyst for going to war - there has never been a humanitarian crisis of this nature that moved the world to intervene.  Historically, all interventions were politically and/or financially motivate (if not directly predicated on self-survival.      As Stalin said, "One death is a tragedy, a million deaths is a statistic."  Despite the consequences this article reveals to thoughtful individuals, this is not the smoking gun needed for the world to turn against Assad, nor will this "revelation" impact its relationships with its allies and protectors - all of whom already engage in this type of behavior. The war in Syria is winding down. With the U.S. moving to withdraw support for the SDF, and Assad enjoying continued assistance from Russia, it is unlikely the remaining revolutionaries will be able to force him from power. It is similarly unlikely that a major power will suddenly step in to attempt to oust him, and he will certainly not step down voluntarily. The chance of him losing power is roughly the chance of him dying of natural causes, plus the chance that someone assassinates him or that a foreign power puts him in a situation where he must step down, plus the chance that something unexpected happens. I estimate the odds of each of these to be very low, but perhaps together they add up to 1% or thereabouts.

Assad has essentially won the civil war which broke out in 2011. While his autocratic rule was once threatened, he is now making attempts to re-establish himself as a world leader on the international stage. Formerly opposed to Assad, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, and other regional actors have already accepted the undeniable reality on the battlefield that Assad is victorious and there is no chance of a rebel victory.  After the outbreak of the Civil war in 2011 and the support to the rebels by almost all the West (with also a military support in the case of the USA), Syrian president Assad seemed doomed to disappear from the political scene, and probably also from the world itself. However, Russia's intervention has upset the course of events, progressively re-establishing Assad into power. On the other hand, the US, regardless still condemning Assad, after the election of Trump lost interest in the Syrian conflicts (albeit showing the muscles in the aftermaths of some human rights violations like the 2017 gas attack). Furthermore, with the support of Iran and Russia, Assad has also now achieved to defeat ISIS. The majority of the internal population is exhausted after 8 years of conflict and now wants stability, no matter if this means having still Assad in charge.  That said, reconstruction funding for Syria is estimated at $400 billion. Therefore, it is also likely that Syria will need substantial assistance from the United States and/or the European Union.  In exchange for financial help, the West might ask for “Assad’s head” or at least for new democratic elections. However, Assad enjoys the full support of Putin hence he is unlikely to accept such a compromise, at least not before the end of his 7-year term. U.S. Moves Some Cargo From Syria but Pace of Withdrawal Still Uncertain. Youssef and Nissenbaum (2019) Jan. 11, stated that: WASHINGTON—The U.S. military has begun moving equipment out of Syria as it pushes forward on President Trump’s order to withdraw forces, but planners are still working out details of how and when more than 2,000 troops will leave, defense officials said Friday (Para.1). Some logistical and support troops have now moved into Syria, after first going to Kuwait and Iraq, to help with an eventual U.S. withdrawal, defense officials said. At the same time, a small number of U.S. troops operating in Syria left in the past week, and a limited quantity of nonessential equipment has been moved out, usually on helicopters that delivered other cargo to Syria. The U.S. military also is putting Navy ships, aircraft and personnel into place to support troops as they withdraw, particularly at the vulnerable point when forces are leaving the country. Despite those movements, the U.S. military has said the pullout is in its initial stages and that officials are largely working to position forces and equipment in the region ahead of the withdrawal. The exit plan is slated to take roughly four months, the officials said. Complicating the planning is the timing of the withdrawal. While U.S. forces usually leave at the end of a conflict, in this instance, they likely will be battling Islamic State even as they are moving out, officials noted. Cmdr. Sean Robertson, a Pentagon spokesman, said late Friday that the military has taken “a number of logistical measures” to support the withdrawal but hasn’t begun to formally redeploy troops. “The withdrawal is based on operational conditions on the ground, including conversation with our allies and partners, and is not subject to an arbitrary timeline,” he said (Para. 1-6). Youssef, N., A. & Nissenbaum, D. (2019). U.S. Moves Some Cargo From Syria but Pace of Withdrawal Still Uncertain. The Wall Street Journal. World. Jan. 11, 2019. Retrieved from

Assad is secure and the civil war is drawing down. None of the major players with a stake in the conflict are actively calling for his removal (Turkey, in particular, has reigned in its rhetoric and western powers are fairly impotent now). There is a historic precedent for infighting within the Syrian regime leading to the removal of leaders. However, Hafez Al Assad removed most potential mechanisms for this kind of leadership change. Moreover, although the civil war is winding down, Assad's supporters are unlikely to abandon him when there are still significant challenges to his consolidation of control over the country: think of the Kurdish-led SDF in the north-east of the country, the presence of the Turkish army in Afrin, and the continuing presence of terrorist groups in areas ostensibly under govt control (think of the IS-claimed Suweida attacks in July 2018 for example) Taking the outside view, I haven't dived into this in detail, but the political leaders of the victorious sides in civil wars rarely step down that soon after victory. I have found no examples of this from the past 20 years. Perhaps there are cases of leaders stepping down after a negotiated end to hostilities, but 'negotiated' is the key word there. Assad has won through strength (amply abetted by Iranian troops and Russian jets of course), and while local ceasefires may slow the government advance, they are very unlikely to stop it. Assad is still fairly young (53 years) and a challenger for the presidency could only emerge from within the regime, unlikely within the next 1-2 years given his role as a figurehead for regime supporters throughout the civil war. The five percent accounts for the unexpected (i.e. Assad's assassination or his sudden stepping down in favour of a hand-picked successor)
